newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary to build two stand-by gas power stations.
newsitem.headline: Hungary to build two stand-by gas power stations.

text.p: Hungary's national electricity company Magyar Villamos Muvek Rt (MVM) will build two open-cycle gas turbine reserve power plants of 100-120 megawatts each by mid-1998, the company said on Wednesday.
"We have to build these plants in order to meet west European electricity network standards," Antal Tombor, MVM deputy general director, told Reuters.
Hungary joined the Union for the Production and Transmission of Electricity (UCPTE) at the end of 1995.
Tombor added that the new plants, to be used as back-up in case of a breakdown in the Hungarian supply system, will have to come on-line within 10 to 15 minutes after a failure.
He also said the plants will be built in Sajoszoged, north-east Hungary and Liter, central Hungary.

Tombor said the international tender for the construction of the new power plants -- with four foreign bidders standing -- would probably be evaluated within a month. The project would be financed from MVM's own sources and World Bank loans.
